questions.explanation: Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C). Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Diagnosis of a disease before the critical point has a good outcome and reduces the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point; treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis, that is, conditions with a long lead time. Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

questions.question: In which of the following diseases, does the screening procedure increase the overall survival to the maximum?
questions.explanation: Screening of colon cancer increases the overall survival to the maximum. Colon cancer has a long lead time and can be detected early before pathological changes occur. It can be curable if treated early; otherwise, it is fatal in half the cases. Early diagnosis and treatment before the critical point have a good outcome and reduce the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point; treatment would be unsuccessful, and/or permanent damage would have occurred. Other diseases that can be screened are: cervical cancer, breast cancer, and prostate cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

options.A: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
options.C: Pap smear in women above 40 years
options.D: Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.explanation: Annual health checkups are an example of multiphasic screening. Types of screening: • Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a large number of people at one time. Example: Annual health checkups. • High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. Example: MRI screening of the breast done annually in 25-year-old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in a first-degree relative. • Mass screening is the screening of a whole or large population, like using a chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.question: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

options.B: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
options.D: Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.explanation: When a large number of tests are done in series, net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is increased. Screening tests are done in series when the result of the first test determines whether to run the second test or not. e.g., HIV screening is done using consecutive ELISA. Screening tests are done in parallel when the second test is independently performed regardless of what the first test result is. Both the tests are done at the same time. For e.g., In LFT, multiple tests are done together like SGOT, SGPT, total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, etc. Following are the trends that are observed while evaluating screening tests: Tests in Series - Tests in Parallel: Combined sensitivity decreases - increases, Combined specificity increases - decreases, Combined PPV increases - decreases, Combined NPV decreases - increases.

questions.question: Blood pressure is measured in an individual 5 times a day under the same conditions by anew screening test. All 5 readings obtained are the almost same. What is the attribute of anew screening test being described?
questions.explanation: The attribute of a new screening test to yield the same reading when repeated under the sameconditions is called reliability.Reliability is also called precision or reproducibility.

questions.question: Ten successive readings of hemoglobin level of a single sample measured by a new method are given below. The hemoglobin level measured by the previous standard test was 10.2. What is true regarding the new method?
questions.explanation: The new method for measuring hemoglobin has high validity and high reliability. The new test gives consistent values on repeat testing, thus it has high reliability. The mean value of all the readings is close to the value of 10.2, which is obtained from the standard test, making the validity high. The validity of a test implies that the test must give correct and accurate results. It represents the closeness to a true/actual value. The reliability of a test implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

questions.question: A researcher finds out a sensitive test to be positive for a person. For diagnosis, which of the following will hold true?

options.A: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
options.B: It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
options.C: It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
options.D: It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.explanation: A sensitive test, if it is positive, confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common. The sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease. In other words, sensitivity is the ability of a test to detect true positives (TP) out of total disease (TP+FN). Sensitivity = TP/ TP+FN

questions.question: If a patient tests positive for a disease, which of the following represents the probability of her actually having the disease?
questions.explanation: Positive predictive value implies the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having the disease. It is the ability of a test to detect true positives (TP) out of total positives (TP+FP) and it is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. PPV = TP/(TP+FP)

questions.explanation: The denominator for the calculation of the positive predictive value of a screening test is truepositives + false positives.Positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is TP/(TP + FP) x 100.It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease. It is directlyproportional to the prevalence of a disease.Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. However, it is affected themost by prevalence.

questions.question: Which of the following maximally affects the positive predictive value of a test?
questions.explanation: Positive predictive value (PPV) is maximally affected by the prevalence of the disease. If the prevalence of a disease in a population is high, the higher will be the positive predictive value of a screening test, and the more accurate will be the test. If the prevalence declines, the PPV will be low. PPV is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. It is affected the most by prevalence. However, both sensitivity and specificity can change the predictive value.

questions.question: Screening of 100 immigrants for COVID-19 with a new test showed 48 positive and 52 people negative. Those who tested negative underwent RT-PCR, out of which 25 came positive. Which of the following is lowest for the new test compared to RT-PCR?
questions.explanation: The sensitivity of the new screening test is low compared to RT-PCR. The new screening test showed 52 people negative, out of which 25 are detected positive by RT-PCR, i.e., 25 are false negatives. The false-negative rate is the number of false negatives out of the total people having the disease. False-negative rate = 1 - Sensitivity. The false-negative rate increases as sensitivity decreases. In this scenario, because the new test has more false negatives, it would have low sensitivity as compared to RT-PCR.

questions.question: While screening a disease with a new screening test, the test is positive in many patients who actually don't have the disease. Which of the following is true?
questions.explanation: The given new screening test has low specificity. The test is positive in many patients who actually don't have the disease, i.e., high false positives. The false-positive rate is the number of false positives out of the total non-diseased. False-positive rate = 1 - Specificity. The false-positive rate is inversely proportional to specificity. Hence, the given test with high false positives will have low specificity. Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP / (TP + FP). It shows the positive predictive value (PPV) of the test decreases with an increase in false positives. An increase in the false-positive does not affect the prevalence of the disease. The prevalence of a disease depends on the incidence (I) and duration (D) of the disease. Prevalence = I x D.

questions.question: Due to an effective prevention program, the prevalence of a disease in a community has been reduced by 90%. However, the physicians continue to use the same screening test for that disease. Which of the following changes is expected to be seen?
questions.explanation: If the prevalence of the disease falls, the negative predictive value (NPV) increases. The NPV of the test is inversely proportional to the prevalence of a disease. The PPV of the test is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. Sensitivity and specificity are independent of the prevalence of the disease in the area. They do not change with the change in prevalence.

questions.explanation: The positive predictive value (PPV) of the test is 54.3%.The prevalence of the disease is 20% in 10000, i.e., 2000 people have the disease(TP + FN) and8000 are disease-free (FP + TN).The sensitivity of the test is 95%, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 95%.Thus, the true positives (TP)= 95/100 x (TP + FN) = 95/100 x 2000 = 1900.The specificity of the test is 80%, i.e. TN/(FP + TN) = 80%.Thus, the true negatives (TN)= 80/100 x (FP + TN) = 80/100 x 8000 = 6400.The given data is represented below:TP-true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negativeFrom the above table, PPV is calculated as TP/(TP + FP) x 100 = 1900/3500 = 54.3%.An alternate formula (Bayes theorem) that can be used is PPV = (Sn x P) / (Sn x P)+[(1-Sp)(1-P)]Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- SpecificityDisease + Disease - TotalTest+1900(TP) 1600(FP)Test100(FN)3500(TP+FP)6400(TN) 6500(FN+TN)Total2000(TP+FN)8000(FP 10000+TN)

questions.question: The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. The diagnostic test for this disease has a specificity of 0.80 and a sensitivity of 0.90. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.explanation: The negative predictive value of the above test is 95%. For convenience, let us assume that the total population in this scenario is 100. The prevalence of the disease is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30 (TP+FN) and disease-free (FP+TN) is 70. Since sensitivity is 0.90, i.e., TP/(TP + FN) = 90%. The total true positives (TP) = 90/100 x (TP+FN) = 90/100 x 30 = 27. False-negative (FN) = 30-27 = 3. Since specificity is 0.80, i.e., TN/(FP+TN) = 80%. Total true negatives (TN) = (FP+TN) x 80/100 = 70 x 80/100 = 56. False-positive (FP) = 70-56 = 14. The given data is represented below: Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%. An alternate formula (Bayes theorem) that can be used is NPV = (1-P) x Sp / [P x (1-Sn)] + [(1-P) x Sp]. Sn = Sensitivity, P = Prevalence, Sp = Specificity.
